review_title: I thoroughly enjoy working for Victim Support, but it is no easy job
job_title: Service Delivery Volunteer in Leeds, England
pros:
I receive very close support and guidance from managerial staff. In the early stages of my work, when things were new, I had consistent supervision and guidance which was incredibly helpful. When I first started, I received monthly supervision meetings with my manager, which were incredibly helpful (to say the least!). These meetings gradually taper off as you gain more experience, but supervision sessions are extremely useful and you can always call in or email for further help with specific cases. 

As a volunteer I meet monthly with other volunteers and guest speakers (virtually due to COVID - in usual times I understand that these sessions would take place in person). I really enjoy speaking to and supporting clients, and VS is a very supportive and fulfilling workplace. VS also offers free private counselling for all volunteers (which I have not used, but can appreciate is a very good workplace benefit). 

The time I have spent working for VS has been during the pandemic. Although I have not yet physically met any staff members at VS Leeds, I have really felt a sense of community within the workplace. I also like that the position is flexible - when I first started I was unsure what 'flexibility' would encompass. I receive clients suitable to me - my clients match my remit/level of training. I choose my own shifts, I stick to them, there are no set deadlines for work (so long as I call clients at our arranged time). I also quite like that support takes place over the phone and I can work from home, at least for now, though home visits would be good too. I like that I have received a volunteer phone too for texting. This position has given me a great sense of fulfilment and I am proud to work for Victim Support.
cons:
For prospective applicants, I will say that the interview process is (justifiably) difficult and does require 'revision',, like you would in secondary school for an exam. It is a long process with intensive training and you really do have to remember everything (and take notes!) to receive/pass your accreditation. It is also nerve wracking to have your manager listening in and taking notes on your first session with a victim - but it really is ultimately very helpful for feedback and self-improvement. The training is also quite intense but is very useful, and you have to keep a mental note of all that you learn... it will help when you begin solo support.

Another 'con' might be that you don't know what you're going to get - it may be an ASB case, a fraud/forgery or a GBH assault, and you need to recall specific training and know how to tailor support to the individual on the spot. Thankfully there is a huge amount of crime-specific guidance on Surf, honestly I couldn't have coped without it at the start. Importantly, the final interview questions are HARD and you will need to remember everything from training, in detail, and apply it to your work.

Volunteering for VS has also occasionally made me feel a failure. When I cannot fully guide the victim towards their preferred outcome; if they make a formal complaint about my support; if they show little improvement across support, it can feel personally discouraging. It's part of the job - impartiality is crucial, but sometimes that can be difficult. Whilst the job is flexible and very volunteer-oriented, it can be taxing. You grow to like your clients, you enjoy speaking to them. When support is unsuccessful, that can be hard.

I feel honoured to have work with a group of people who are supportive, friendly, dedicated and caring. I couldn’t have asked for better colleagues.
I also enjoyed working in a environment which was diverse with people from  various different backgrounds.
I gained knowledge and experience of the criminal justice system, The impact of crime and domestic violence.
cons:
Whilst working at Victim Support I experienced bullying and micromanagement from managers.
I feel that management cared too much about tick box Exercises rather than victims and employee well-being.
Caseloads were too high with unrealistic expectations from management.
Managers seem to be on different pages when it came to casework guidance and policies and this lead to confusion.

pros: Great place to work, lovely

job_title: Call Centre Agent in Birmingham, England
pros:
Good place to learn professional interpersonal skills.
Rewarding to help victims of crime and know that you've helped them get their lives back on track.
After the main office was closed and we all moved to local branches, the atmosphere felt much better.
At least the pay was alright
cons:
My work location was essentially a call centre. Management would sit at one end of the room or in the office, away from everyone else. Would only speak to you if you've not hit targets for getting as many support needs boxes ticked. 

There was also a culture of bullying and harassment at the time. Wouldn't be surprised if nothing has changed. Senior management carried themselves like they were unaccountable for any decisions made or actions taken against employees

Staff were not involved in any discussions regarding contracts or the company's future until it was too late and a bunch of staff were going to leave because the region they served wouldn't be served by the company any more.
At the location that I worked, the management was terrible - insecure, jealous, vindictive, nepotist, full of problems, people would look for anything to call you out on. Complaints were thrown around like M&Ms, staff were scared to even open their mouths if what they were talking about wasn't work-related, even in the breakout area, was like a constant war zone. So much bitchiness and cliqueyness going on. Honestly, I don't think anyone there who isn't brownnosing the management could really tell you what the company's values are.

No career opportunities unless you were willing to politick and brown-nose or undertake a multi-year degree/diploma in management

job_title: Call Centre Adviser in Manchester, England
pros: I worked at Victim Support for many years and found it to be at least a good place to get some basic interpersonal skills and experience.  You learn to communicate in a professional manner.  It is also rewarding helping victims of crime.
cons: I would never work there again  as throughout my time I witnessed bullying and harassment from management, to my fellow colleagues.  They will use whatever means to act improperly, and can even use emotional blackmail.  Even the HR department are disgraceful.  Even when leaving the organisation they tried to stop me leaving under the contractual terms I agreed to.  I had to use legal action to get them to let me leave according to the contract.  There are not many promotion opportunities

review_title: An impersonal approach to support which felt like being in a call centre
job_title: Victim Care Officer in Wakefield, England
pros: Many colleagues were pleasant for the most part (and a couple were lovely).
cons:
Old fashioned management style, such as the manager of the service being shut up in a separate office all day every day. I also do not feel that staff were included at all in discussions regarding contracts and going to tender etc. Staff were also not involved or included in wider organisational decisions or the general goings-on of the organisation as a whole. I doubt any staff members in operations could tell you what Victim Support's aims or values are. 

Team leaders were very nit-picky, such as noting if a person was a couple of minutes late due to the trains and insisting that they make their time back, and having a seating plan for staff as though we were children!

The staff team also could be very cliquey with annoying bitchiness creeping in. I wouldn't say the staff team acted as a team at all, in fact.  

Also, there is no service user involvement whatsoever, or inter-organisational relations. 

The organisations overall HR department was also poor. Upon leaving I  was significantly overpaid which resulted in problems with my tax at the end of the year despite me obviously paying it back straight away. In addition, several months after leaving the company, Victim Support decided to declare that I had reinstated employment with them and that I had been paid a lump sum. This resulted in further persistent issues with HMRC for over 12 months!!
